results.title: At the caribou crossing place. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Education Development Center, Quentin Brown and Kevin Smith
results.brief_description: Part of a series on the Netsilik Inuit as documented by the Education Development Center. In this part, the time is early autumn the place an Inuit camp in the Pelly Bay region of the Canadian Arctic. A woman, a boy and two men are shown occupied with their various activities. A woman works on caribou skins. Men return from the hunt with another caribou. A boy picks berries and then plays at being a hunter.

results.title: At the canoe camp
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, Philip Robertson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
Narritjin Maymuru is leader of the Manggalili clan of northeast Arnhem Land. Covers the daily life of Narritjin and his family at a camp in the bush. Shows the making of dug out canoes. Photography by Dean Semler.

results.title: At the brink
results.creator_credit: Peter Raymont, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Nuclear age”.
In an exclusive interview, former Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko speaks for the first time about his famous White House Meeting with President Kennedy at the height of the Cuban Missile Crisis, and refutes certain claims made at the time. “…Kennedy never raised the question of the presence of Soviet missiles in Cuba. I repeat, he never mentioned it.” The statesman recalled that the discussions were “full of sharp turns.” For the first time since the end of the Second World War, the Cuban Missile crisis brought the world to the brink of a Nuclear war.

results.title: At the borders of the future. [No. 70/17] = Aux frontieres de l'avenir
results.creator_credit: Office de Documentation par Film and Nicolas Skrotsky
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items including: 1. Better building - to build better and cheaper accommodation new techniques are being used but care must be taken to maintain quality. 2. The solar observatory. 3. The artificial kidney - Professor Jungers speaks about the importance of a dialyser or artificial kidney.

results.title: At the autumn river camp. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Education Development Center, Quentin Brown and Kevin Smith
results.brief_description: Part of a series on the Netsilik Inuit as documented by the Education Development Center. In this part, the family moves once again, this time into an igloo built by the men. A sleigh is constructed from skins, frozen fish and caribou antlers. When ready, it is loaded and the family heads down the river to the coast. (Award: Parno)

results.title: At the autumn river camp. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Education Development Center, Quentin Brown and Kevin Smith
results.brief_description: Part of a series on the Netsilik Inuit as documented by the Education Development Center. In this film, it is late autumn. The Inuit move to the river valley where they build karmaks - shelters with snow walls and roofs of skins. The men fish with spears and their catch is cooked over an exterior fire. The family then eats inside the karmak. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: At sea
results.brief_description: Dedicated to the director’s mother who lost her son at sea, Penny Fowler-Smith uses a family member (possibly her mother), as voice over in this reflection on the death of a child. The opening sequence shows a woman slicing oranges, a painful metaphor for the miscarriage she is describing. The sorrow manages to pass as she gives birth to three further children; 2 girls and a boy. “At sea” refers to the tragic journey made to Australia by the director’s mother when she lost her only son. Dedicated to her mother and son, Andrew and featuring the voice of Bremer Fowler-Smith.

results.title: At play in the fields of the Lord
results.creator_credit: Saul Zaentz, Saul Zaentz Company and Hector Babenco
results.brief_description: Tom Berenger, Daryl Hannah and Aidan Quinn star in a powerful story of mercenaries, missionaries and a tribe of primitive Indians who clash in fanatical conflict in the remote and unforgiving forest of Amazonia. A tragic chain of events is set in motion when the modern world intrudes on the rainforest and its indigenous people. Shot entirely on location in the Amazon forest.

results.title: At Patantja clay pan
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones, Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Daily activities of two families camped near a clay pan holding water, showing desert food resources in a good season. The men hunt emus and the women collect mulga seed, ngaru fruit and grubs.
